definition: Clothing; to dress or clothe (formal/old-fashioned as a verb).
examples: The shop sells sports apparel. (noun)
The actors were appareled in bright costumes. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Apparel = a pair of sleeves and more—clothes!

definition: To recognise the value of something; to be grateful for; to increase in value.
examples: I appreciate your help with the project.
Property can appreciate over time.
The machine runs in a continuous cycle.
We heard continuous rain through the night.

definition: To mix with a liquid and become part of it; to end or break up; a gradual transition in film.
examples: Sugar dissolves quickly in hot tea. (verb)
The club voted to dissolve the committee. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Dissolve = dis + solve — break the solid’s ‘solve’.

definition: To tame an animal or adapt a plant for human use; to train for life at home.
examples: Humans domesticated dogs thousands of years ago.
It can be hard to domesticate wild cats.

extra.memory_tip: Domesticate = make ready for the ‘domestic’ home.

definition: To come out into view; to become known.
examples: Butterflies emerge from their chrysalises.
New details emerged after the meeting.

definition: A thread-like part of a material or plant; parts of food that help digestion (UK spelling of ‘fiber’).
examples: Cotton fibres are spun into thread.
Whole grains are high in dietary fibre.

extra.memory_tip: Fibre = fine threads in fabric and food.

definition: The purpose or job of something; to work or operate.
examples: The heart’s function is to pump blood. (noun)
The printer isn’t functioning properly. (verb)

definition: To come out of an egg; to think up a plan; a door or opening in a ship, plane, or floor.
examples: The chicks hatched this morning. (verb)
He climbed through the roof hatch. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Hatch a chick or hatch a plan.

definition: To hold back, slow down, or prevent an action or process.
examples: Cold temperatures inhibit plant growth.
Shyness can inhibit speaking in class.

definition: A unit of time equal to sixty seconds; very small or detailed.
examples: The lesson starts in five minutes. (noun)
They found minute traces of salt. (adjective)

extra.memory_tip: Same spelling, two sounds: MIN-it (time), my-NOOT (tiny).

definition: Movement; a formal proposal; to signal by moving your hand or head.
examples: The camera detects motion. (noun)
She motioned for us to sit. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Motion = move; emotion = energy in motion.

definition: To put a blade or tool into its cover; to cover something like a sheath.
examples: The knight sheathed his sword.
Cables are sheathed in plastic for safety.

extra.memory_tip: Sheathe = sheath + e; put it in the sheath.

definition: To let something fall or drop; to get rid of; a small simple building for storage.
examples: Snakes shed their skin each year. (verb)
The tools are in the garden shed. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Shed tears, shed leaves, or build a shed.

definition: To move from one place, person, or thing to another; the act of moving.
examples: Please transfer the files to the new folder. (verb)
We made a bank transfer yesterday. (noun)
